recycling.recycleButtonTooltip: Reset the status of all records with this qualification.

planning.clearAllSuccess: The schedule has been completely cleared.
planning.clearAllError: An error occurred while clearing the schedule.

manual.title: Manual Backup
manual.description: Start a full backup of the system configuration at any time. Useful before major changes.
manual.info: The backup includes users, groups, scripts, IVRs, campaigns, and all settings. Call recordings are not included.
manual.confirm: Are you sure you want to start a manual backup now?

history.title: Backup History
history.confirmRestore: Are you sure you want to restore the backup '{fileName}'? All current data will be overwritten.
history.confirmRestore_final: IRREVERSIBLE ACTION. Do you confirm the restore? The application will be temporarily unavailable.
history.restoreSuccess: Restore completed. The application will now restart.

databaseManager.attention: Warning: Actions performed here directly modify the database. Use this tool with extreme caution. Any data loss is irreversible.

users.title: Users
users.description: Manage employee accounts, their roles, and permissions.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: An administrator logs into the platform.
They navigate to the 'Users' section to add a new agent.
They fill out the form with the agent's information (name, login ID, password) and assign the 'Agent' role.
They assign the agent to one or more groups and campaigns.
The agent can now log in with their credentials and start working.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Storage of passwords as secure hashes (bcrypt) in the database.
Input validation (uniqueness of login ID, email format).
Role-based access control (RBAC).
Possibility of bulk import/export (CSV/Excel).

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: For a small team, you can do without 'Groups' and directly assign agents to campaigns for more direct management.

groups.title: Groups
groups.description: Create agent groups for simplified management and call routing.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A supervisor wants to create a specialized 'Level 2 Support' team.
They go to 'Groups' and create a new group with this name.
They then select the expert agents from the member list.
The group can now be used to assign campaigns or for inbound call routing.
When an agent leaves the team, they are simply removed from the group.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: A many-to-many relationship table between users and groups.
The interface must allow for easy selection/deselection of members.
Deleting a group should not delete the user members.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Start with a single 'All Agents' group. Only add new groups when you have teams with genuinely distinct skills or tasks.

planning.title: Planning
planning.description: Manage weekly agent schedules and their different activities.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The planner opens the 'Planning' view.
They select a group of agents, for example, 'Morning Team'.
They click and drag on the 9am-12pm time slot on Monday to create an event.
They assign the 'Promo Campaign' activity to this event.
They use the recurrence feature to apply this slot to the entire week.
The agent, upon logging in, can see their personal schedule for the day.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Integration of a frontend calendar library (e.g., FullCalendar).
Storage of events with support for recurrence rules (iCalendar RRULE).
API to retrieve events by period, agent, or group.
Configurable activity types (Break, Meeting, Call) by the administrator.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Instead of scheduling each agent individually, schedule by groups. This allows you to manage the entire team in just a few clicks.

outbound.title: Outbound Campaigns
outbound.description: Create and manage outbound call campaigns with advanced calling strategies.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A campaign manager clicks 'Create Campaign'.
They name the campaign, choose the dialing mode (e.g., Predictive), and assign an agent script.
They define the calling hours (e.g., 9am-6pm, Monday to Friday).
They import a contact file (CSV) by matching the columns (name, phone, etc.).
They assign the 'Sales' agent group to the campaign.
They activate the campaign for agents to start receiving calls.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Robust import module (CSV, Excel) with field mapping and deduplication.
Configuration of retry strategies (number of attempts, intervals).
Quota management (e.g., do not exceed 50 sales in Paris).
Exclusion/inclusion rules to filter which contacts to call.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Start with 'Manual' or 'Progressive' dialing mode. 'Predictive' mode is powerful but requires fine-tuning to be effective and compliant.

scripts.title: Agent Scripts
scripts.description: Build interactive call guides for your agents with a visual editor.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A supervisor opens the script editor for a new campaign.
They drag and drop a 'Text' block for the welcome message.
They add an 'Input' field for the customer's name and a 'Single Choice' for the call outcome.
They create a second page for objections and add a 'Back' button to it on the first page.
They preview the script to ensure it displays correctly for the agent.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Saving the script structure in JSON format in the database.
A frontend rendering engine that interprets the JSON to display the form to the agent.
Management of block positioning (x, y) and sizing (width, height).
Navigation logic between script pages.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Your script doesn't need to be complex. Often, a simple guide with key points and fields to fill in is more effective than an overly directive script.

ivr.title: IVR Flows
ivr.description: Design complex inbound call journeys with a graphical designer.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The administrator creates a new IVR flow for customer service.
They add a 'Media' node with a welcome message.
They connect this node to a 'Menu': 'Press 1 for support, 2 for sales'.
Option 1 is connected to a 'Transfer' node to the 'Support' group.
Option 2 is connected to another 'Transfer' to the 'Sales' group.
They add a 'Voicemail' node in case of no answer.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Storage of the IVR structure (nodes and connections) in JSON format.
A server-side script (AGI) that interprets the JSON to control the call in Asterisk.
Drag-and-drop interface for an intuitive user experience.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Avoid overly long IVRs. A simple menu with 2 or 3 options followed by a transfer is often the solution most appreciated by callers.

audio.title: Media Library
audio.description: Import and manage audio files for IVRs and hold music.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The administrator receives a new MP3 file for the welcome message.
They go to the 'Media Library' and click 'Upload'.
They select the file and give it a descriptive name, e.g., 'Welcome_Main_EN'.
They can listen to the file to verify it's the correct one.
The file is now available to be selected in the 'Media' nodes of the IVR editor.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Storage of audio files on the server in a standardized format (e.g., .wav, .gsm).
Automatic conversion of audio formats upon upload.
Validation of file type and maximum size.
Association of metadata (name, duration) in the database.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use clear file names and a logical structure. For example, prefix all English messages with 'EN_' to find them easily.

records.title: Recordings
records.description: Listen to, download, and archive call recordings for quality and compliance.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A supervisor wants to review a call from agent Alice.
They go to 'Recordings' and filter by agent 'Alice' and yesterday's date.
They find the relevant call in the list and click 'Listen'.
They can listen to the entire conversation via the integrated player.
If they need to share the call, they click 'Download' to get the audio file.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Enabling recording in Asterisk (MixMonitor).
Storage of audio files on accessible storage.
Search interface with powerful filters (indexed on dates, agents, etc.).
HTML5 audio player for direct playback in the browser.
Retention policies to automatically delete old recordings.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Only enable recording for campaigns where it is necessary. Recording consumes disk space and may be subject to legal constraints.

qualifications.title: Call Qualifications
qualifications.description: Define call ending statuses for reporting and callback strategies.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The campaign manager needs new qualifications for a survey campaign.
They create a qualification group named 'Opinion Poll'.
They add custom qualifications like 'Survey completed' (Positive), 'Refused to answer' (Negative), and 'Call back later' (Neutral).
They then assign the 'Opinion Poll' group to their campaign.
Agents on this campaign will see these qualifications at the end of their calls.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Table for qualifications (code, description, type: positive/negative/neutral).
Table for qualification groups.
Link between campaigns and qualification groups.
Standard qualifications (Answering Machine, Busy, etc.) should be available for all campaigns.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Limit the number of qualifications to the essentials (less than 10-12 per group). Too many choices can slow down agents and complicate reports.

supervision.title: Real-Time Supervision
supervision.description: View your contact center activity live and interact with agents.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A supervisor opens the supervision dashboard.
They see in real-time that 3 agents are waiting, 5 are on a call, and 2 are on break.
They notice that an agent, Bob, has been in wrap-up for too long.
They can see the list of active calls, their duration, and the associated campaign.
They can choose to discreetly listen to a call to assess quality.
If an agent needs help, they can intervene directly in the conversation (barge-in).

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Connection to the Asterisk Manager Interface (AMI) to receive real-time events.
Use of WebSockets to push updates from the backend to the frontend without delay.
AMI commands for supervision actions (ChanSpy, Barge).
Aggregation of data for global KPIs (number of agents per state).

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Focus on key indicators: the number of agents waiting (ready to take calls) and the number of calls in the queue. These are the two most important metrics for managing activity.

reporting.title: Reports & Analytics
reporting.description: Explore historical data, create custom reports, and export results.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A manager wants to analyze last week's performance.
They go to the 'Reports' section and select the date range.
They consult the global KPIs (number of calls, average duration, etc.).
They look at the qualification distribution chart to see the most frequent call outcomes.
They examine the performance table by agent to identify top performers.
They export the full report in PDF for their weekly meeting.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Aggregated SQL queries to calculate statistics (COUNT, SUM, AVG).
Use of a charting library (e.g., Chart.js) for data visualization.
Efficient database filtering logic.
Client-side PDF generation (e.g., jsPDF, html2canvas).

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Don't get lost in dozens of metrics. Track 3 to 5 key indicators that are truly important for your goals (e.g., Conversion Rate, Average Talk Time).

history.title: Call History
history.description: View, filter, and search the detailed log of all inbound and outbound calls.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A customer complains about not being called back.
A supervisor goes to the history and searches for the customer's phone number.
They find all calls made with that number.
They see which agent handled the last call and what qualification was applied.
They can click on the call to see details and listen to the recording if available.
They now have all the information to contact the customer again.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: A well-indexed `call_history` table (CDR - Call Detail Records) for fast searches.
Server-side pagination to handle large volumes of data.
Combinable filters (date, agent, campaign, number, etc.).
Display of related information (agent name, campaign name) via SQL joins.
Infinite scrolling on the frontend for a smooth user experience.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use the most restrictive filters first (like phone number) to speed up your searches before using broader filters like date ranges.

sessions.title: Agent Login/Logout
sessions.description: View the detailed log of agent connections, disconnections, and work times.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The HR department needs to verify an agent's working hours for payroll.
The manager goes to 'Agent Login/Logout' and filters by the agent and the relevant period.
They see a list of all the agent's sessions, with login time, logout time, and total duration.
They can export this data to integrate it into their payroll system.
They can also identify anomalies, such as unusually long or short sessions.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: An `agent_sessions` table with agent ID, login time, and logout time.
Updating the table via triggers at login and logout in the backend.
Server-side pagination for displaying the history.
Calculation of durations and totals via SQL queries.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: This module is primarily a verification tool. For in-depth analysis of work times, cross-reference this data with performance reports to see time spent in each status (on call, on break, etc.).

trunks.title: SIP Trunks
trunks.description: Connect your telephone carriers for inbound and outbound calls.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The company subscribes to a new SIP operator.
The system administrator goes to 'SIP Trunks' and clicks 'Add'.
They fill in the information provided by the operator: name, domain/IP, username, and password.
They save the configuration.
The trunk is now available to be used in outbound routes.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Dynamic generation of Asterisk's PJSIP configuration files.
Management of both authentication types: by registration and by IP.
Automatic reloading of Asterisk's PJSIP configuration after modification.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use IP authentication whenever possible. It's simpler to configure and more secure if you have a static IP address.

dids.title: Numbers (DIDs)
dids.description: Manage your inbound phone numbers and their initial routing.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The company gets a new phone number for the sales department.
The administrator goes to 'Numbers (DIDs)' and adds this new number.
They associate it with the SIP trunk of the provider who supplied it.
In the 'Routing' section, they select the 'Sales Welcome' IVR flow they previously created.
They save. Calls to this number will now be directed to the sales IVR.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: A `dids` table to store numbers and their associations.
The Asterisk dialplan must be configured to query this table to determine routing.
Link to the `trunks` and `ivr_flows` tables.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Even if you only have one number, configure it here and associate it with a simple IVR. This will give you the flexibility to change the routing later without touching the technical configuration.

sites-config.title: Site Configuration
sites-config.description: Manage different physical sites for outbound call routing.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The company opens a new branch in Lyon.
The administrator goes to 'Site Configuration' and creates a 'Lyon' site.
They enter the IP address of the telephone gateway (e.g., Yeastar) of the Lyon branch.
They then go to 'Users' and assign the Lyon agents to this new site.
Now, when these agents make a call, the system will know to route it through the Lyon gateway.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: A `sites` table to store the name and IP of each site's gateway.
Logic in the Asterisk dialplan to retrieve the agent's site and use the corresponding PJSIP trunk.
A script to dynamically add the PJSIP configuration for a new site.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: If you only have one physical site, create a single 'Main' site and assign all your agents to it. This will allow the system to function correctly.

module-settings.title: Module Management
module-settings.description: Enable or disable menus for administrator and supervisor roles.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: The SuperAdmin decides that supervisors should not be able to modify SIP Trunks.
They go to 'Module Management'.
They uncheck the 'SIP Trunks' box for the 'Supervisor' role.
They save the changes.
Now, when a supervisor logs in, the 'SIP Trunks' menu no longer appears in the sidebar.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Storage of visibility preferences in JSON in the database or a configuration file.
The backend sends these preferences during the initial application load.
The frontend uses this data to dynamically show or hide menu items.
Important: security must also be applied on the backend to block access to the corresponding APIs.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: By default, leave all modules enabled. Only hide features if you have a specific management or security reason to limit a certain role's access.

languages.title: Languages
languages.description: Manage the available languages in the application.

userJourney.title: User Journey
steps: A user selects a language from the language switcher.
The interface instantly updates to display content in the chosen language.
This choice is saved for the user's next visits.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Use of JSON translation files (one per language).
Integration of an i18n library (like i18next) to manage language switching and key translation.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: The 'Languages' menu is a placeholder. Language management is done via the switcher in the header for quick and intuitive access.

database-client.title: Database
database-client.description: Execute SQL queries directly on the database for debugging and advanced reporting.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: An administrator needs a very specific statistic not available in standard reports.
They go to the 'Database' client.
They write an SQL query, for example: 'SELECT COUNT(*) FROM contacts WHERE postal_code LIKE '75%';'.
They ensure 'Read-Only' mode is enabled.
They execute the query and get the result directly in the interface.
They can copy-paste the results for their analysis.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: A text editor for writing SQL queries.
A secure API endpoint that receives the query and executes it on the database.
A 'Read-Only' mode that blocks non-SELECT queries (UPDATE, DELETE, etc.) on the backend.
Display of results in a table format.
Security: access to this module must be strictly limited to the SuperAdmin role.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use the 'Predefined Queries' as a starting point. They provide useful examples and can be modified for your specific needs.

system-connection.title: System Connection
system-connection.description: Configure connections to the database and the Asterisk telephony server.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: During the initial installation, or if the database password changes.
The SuperAdmin goes to 'System Connection'.
They update the database server's IP address or the new password.
They do the same for the Asterisk AMI connection information.
They save the changes.
They are informed that a restart of the backend service is required to apply the changes.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: The interface reads the current values from an API endpoint (which should never return passwords).
When saving, the API updates the backend's environment configuration file (e.g., .env).
Passwords are only updated if explicitly provided.
A connection test mechanism for each service (database, AMI) is highly recommended.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use this menu with extreme caution. A misconfiguration here can make the entire application unavailable. Only change these settings if you are sure of what you are doing.

api-docs.title: API Documentation
api-docs.description: View the complete API documentation for integration and development.

userJourney.title: Typical User Journey
steps: A developer wants to integrate an external tool with the CRM.
They go to the 'API Documentation' section.
There, they find the list of all available endpoints, formatted with Swagger/OpenAPI.
They can see the required parameters, request bodies, and response formats for each endpoint.
They can even test the endpoints directly from this interface.

specs.title: Technical Specifications
points: Automatic generation of documentation from comments in the backend code (e.g., JSDoc, Swagger).
Use of `swagger-ui-express` to display the interactive interface.
The interface is embedded in an `iframe` in the frontend.

simplificationTip.title: Simplification Tip
simplificationTip.content: Use the 'Authorize' button at the top of the documentation page to enter your authentication token. This will allow you to test endpoints that require you to be logged in.

billing.title: Billing
billing.description: Manage subscriptions and view billing history.

system-settings.title: System
system-settings.description: Configure low-level system settings, such as email sending.

help.title: Help Center
help.description: Find answers to your questions and guides on the features.

maintenance.title: Maintenance
maintenance.description: Manage backups, restores, and overall system health.
